claim: Some people soak in olive oil and water.

supporting.text: There is no widespread cultural or medical practice that involves soaking in olive oil and water, as it lacks documented benefits or historical precedent.

attacks.text: There is no widespread cultural or medical practice that involves soaking in olive oil and water, as it lacks documented benefits or historical precedent.
Some Mediterranean cultures historically used olive oil in bathing rituals for skin care, though not necessarily combined with water.
Modern spa treatments sometimes incorporate olive oil in water-based therapies, suggesting contemporary adoption of the practice.
The absence of widespread documentation doesn't preclude niche or localized practices that may exist without formal records.
Olive oil's hygroscopic properties make it biologically plausible as a skin treatment when combined with water.

supporting.text: Olive oil is primarily used for cooking and skincare applications, not for full-body soaking, which would be impractical and wasteful.

attacks.text: Olive oil is primarily used for cooking and skincare applications, not for full-body soaking, which would be impractical and wasteful.
Historical records show that ancient Romans and Greeks used olive oil for bathing and full-body massages, indicating that full-body soaking is not unheard of.
Modern spa treatments in some cultures still incorporate olive oil baths, demonstrating contemporary relevance of the practice.
The cost and quantity of olive oil required for full-body soaking make it impractical for widespread use today.

supporting.text: No major spa or wellness centers promote olive oil and water soaking as a treatment, indicating it is not a recognized therapeutic practice.

attacks.text: No major spa or wellness centers promote olive oil and water soaking as a treatment, indicating it is not a recognized therapeutic practice.
Some niche wellness practitioners and home remedy enthusiasts do promote olive oil and water soaking for skin benefits.
The absence of promotion by major spas does not necessarily mean the practice is ineffective, as major spas often focus on commercially profitable treatments.
Historical and cultural practices in Mediterranean regions have used olive oil for skin care, suggesting some therapeutic value.

supporting.text: Scientific literature does not support the idea that soaking in olive oil and water has any measurable health benefits, further undermining the claim.

attacks.text: Scientific literature does not support the idea that soaking in olive oil and water has any measurable health benefits, further undermining the claim.
Anecdotal evidence from cultures with long-standing traditions of oil-based therapies suggests subjective benefits, even if not scientifically measured.
Subjective benefits without clinical evidence may be placebo effects rather than inherent properties of olive oil.
Some dermatological studies indicate olive oil's emollient properties could theoretically benefit skin when used in immersion.
These studies examine topical application, not full-body immersion, making the relevance to soaking questionable.

supporting.text: The viscosity and cost of olive oil make it an unlikely choice for soaking, as it would require large quantities and create cleanup challenges.

attacks.text: The viscosity and cost of olive oil make it an unlikely choice for soaking, as it would require large quantities and create cleanup challenges.
Olive oil is commonly used in spa treatments and massages, demonstrating its practicality for soaking despite viscosity and cost.
Spa treatments use diluted olive oil or small amounts, not large-scale soaking, which supports A5's point about impracticality for soaking.
Historical records show cultures like ancient Greeks and Romans used olive oil for bathing, proving its feasibility for soaking.
Ancient bathing practices often involved communal or ritual use, not personal soaking, limiting relevance to modern contexts.
